Ruowei Li
Master of Business Analytics, Monash University
Data Analytics & Business Insights Enthusiast

I am currently studying for a Master of Business Analytics at Monash University, where I focus on data analytics, statistical modelling, and data storytelling. I enjoy exploring how data can be used to support business decisions and communicate insights effectively. My key interests include data visualization, predictive analytics, and translating complex results into practical business actions. I work mainly with R, Python, and Quarto, and I value clear and reproducible workflows.
This website is part of my ETC5523 course — Communicating with Data — where I share projects and blog posts that combine analytics, visualization, and communication.

title: Tracking Nitrate in Streams
text:
Healthy rivers are vital for ecosystems and human communities, but invisible pollutants such as nitrate (NO₃⁻) can silently degrade water quality.
Nitrate mainly originates from fertiliser runoff and urban wastewater, and excessive levels lead to eutrophication—the growth of algal blooms that deplete oxygen and threaten aquatic life.
Traditional monitoring based on monthly water samples often misses rapid changes in nitrate levels after rainfall or runoff events.
A recent study by Kermorvant et al. (2023) used high-frequency in-situ sensors to explore how nitrate concentrations vary through time and how they relate to other water-quality variables such as temperature, dissolved oxygen, and turbidity.
The goal was to identify which factors most strongly influence nitrate levels across diverse river environments.

title: Tracking Nitrate in Streams
text:
Healthy rivers are vital for ecosystems and human communities, but invisible pollutants such as nitrate (NO₃⁻) can silently degrade water quality.
Nitrate mainly originates from fertiliser runoff and urban wastewater, and excessive levels lead to eutrophication—the growth of algal blooms that deplete oxygen and threaten aquatic life.
Traditional monitoring based on monthly water samples often misses rapid changes in nitrate levels after rainfall or runoff events.
A recent study by Kermorvant et al. (2023) used high-frequency in-situ sensors to explore how nitrate concentrations vary through time and how they relate to other water-quality variables such as temperature, dissolved oxygen, and turbidity.
The goal was to identify which factors most strongly influence nitrate levels across diverse river environments.

title: Tracking Nitrate in Streams
text:
Analysis
Data source. Data were obtained from the National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON) in the United States. These sensors record readings every few minutes, providing a detailed picture of short-term water-quality dynamics.
Study sites. Three contrasting streams were analysed:



Table 1: Average nitrate across three NEON streams.





Site
Location
Typical nitrate (µM)




Arikaree
Colorado — semi-arid grassland
5.5


Caribou
Alaska — sub-arctic forest
28


Lewis Run
Virginia — agricultural + urban
192






As Table Table 1 shows, Lewis Run (farmland + towns) had nitrate almost 40× higher than Arikaree, highlighting strong land-use effects.

title: Tracking Nitrate in Streams
text:
Findings

library(ggplot2)
df <- data.frame(
  Site = c("Arikaree", "Caribou", "Lewis Run"),
  Nitrate = c(5.5, 28, 192)
)
ggplot(df, aes(Site, Nitrate)) +
  geom_col() +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(y = "Nitrate (µM)")







Figure 1: Nitrate concentrations differ strongly across sites.





As Figure Figure 1 illustrates, nitrate concentrations vary markedly across the three streams, increasing from natural to agricultural catchments. Sensor data also revealed distinct event responses:
At Arikaree, nitrate spiked after rainfall, consistent with fertiliser runoff.
At Lewis Run, heavy flow diluted nitrate because rainfall added relatively clean water.
Statistical modelling identified six important predictors — temperature, dissolved oxygen, turbidity, specific conductance, water level, and time — that together explained about 99 % of nitrate variation. Among these, specific conductance and dissolved oxygen were the most consistent indicators of nitrate change across all sites.

title: Tracking Nitrate in Streams
text:
Conclusion and why it matters
This research highlights how modern sensor technology transforms water-quality monitoring. Continuous, high-frequency data allow scientists and managers to detect nitrate spikes quickly and respond before serious ecological damage occurs.
Two key takeaways stand out:
Local context matters. Each catchment behaves differently; effective management must reflect local land use, climate, and hydrology.
Continuous monitoring pays off. Tracking conductivity, oxygen, and flow provides cost-efficient insights into pollution sources and ecosystem health.
Overall, the study demonstrates that combining sensor data with statistical modelling offers a powerful tool for protecting freshwater systems and informing evidence-based environmental policy.

title: Tracking Nitrate in Streams
text:
Reference
Kermorvant, C., Liquet, B., Litt, G., Wilson, K., & Robertson, A. (2023). Understanding links between water-quality variables and nitrate concentration in freshwater streams using high-frequency sensor data. PLOS ONE, 18(6), e0287640. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0287640
